Background

TeX is a specialized computer language used for typesetting documents. LaTeX is essentially a collection of TeX macros (i.e. shortcuts) that make the process of "programming" a document easy enough for general users. If you've ever used HTML/CSS, the concept is similar.

The basic purpose of using LaTeX rather than Microsoft Word or some other desktop publishing program is that it fully separates formatting from content, making it possible to change the formatting for your document by making changes in only one place. LaTeX also features powerful bibliography and citation features, which are a huge help when writing academic papers. And because TeX is a very good typesetter, it's very easy to get professional-looking results.

But the reason that you really want to learn LaTeX is that it makes it much easier to write papers in subjects like math, philosophy, and linguistics, which use many non-alphabetic symbols and other specialized notations. For linguistics, it will automatically number your examples and format your glosses, and in the case of syntax, it allows you to draw perfect trees.

Despite all of its advantages, LaTeX has a bit of a learning curve. Because of this, we'll start by drawing simple bracketed trees wth the PHP Tree Drawer, and go from there.

Text Editors

LaTeX files are created and modified using a text editor. Bracketed trees (even outside of LaTeX) are likewise easiest to create and modify using a text editor.

Sublime Text

There are many good text editors out there, but for simplicity, everyone should use Sublime Text 2 for these workshops, which works on all major operating systems and has an unlimited free trial.

Notes:

  • When you install Sublime Text, you do not need to check the box that adds the program to the context menu.
  • If you don't like how Sublime Text inserts closing brackets automatically, go to Preferences -> Settings - User and insert the following line between the brackets in the settings file, then save and close:
    • "auto_match_enabled": false

Other Editors

Some other (free and open source) text editors include:

  • Notepad++ (Windows only, very good)
  • Geany (Windows/Linux, similar to Notepad++)
  • jEdit (cross-platform, requires Java, annoying in some places)

Note that the built-in Windows editor, Notepad, lacks auto-indentation and other critical features and is thus nearly useless. TextEdit in OSX is more of a word processor than a text editor and is likewise not appropriate for the task at hand.
